questions.answer_ET: E. Router B will not advertise the 10.0.0.0/8 network because it is blocked by the ACL.

choices.D: Users on the 10.0.0.0/8 network can successfully ping users on the 192.168.5.0/24 network, but users on the 192.168.5.0/24 cannot successfully ping users on the 10.0.0.0/8 network.
choices.C: The 10.0.0.0/8 network will not be in the routing table on Router B.
choices.B: The 10.0.0.0/8 network will not be advertised by Router B because the network statement for the 10.0.0.0/8 network is missing from Router B.
choices.A: Traffic from the 172.16.0.0/16 network will be blocked by the ACL.

questions.answer: E. Router B will not advertise the 10.0.0.0/8 network because it is blocked by the ACL.
questions.answer_description:
You can filter what individual routes are sent (out) or received (in) to any interface within your EIGRP configuration.
One example is noted above. If you filter outbound, the next neighbor(s) will not know about anything except the 172.16.0.0/16 route and therefore won't send it to anyone else downstream. If you filter inbound, YOU won't know about the route and therefore won't send it to anyone else downstream.

discussion.content: E. Router B will not advertise the 10.0.0.0/8 network because it is blocked by the ACL.

questions.answer_ET: D. IPv6 traffic filtering can be implemented only on SVIs.

choices.B: The global anycast address must be added to the traffic filter to allow OSPFv3 to work properly.
choices.C: The link-local addresses that were used by OSPFv3 were explicitly denied, which caused the neighbor relationships to fail.
choices.A: The traffic filter is blocking all ICMPv6 traffic.

questions.question_text:
For security purposes, an IPv6 traffic filter was configured under various interfaces on the local router. However, shortly after implementing the traffic filter,
OSPFv3 neighbor adjacencies were lost. What caused this issue?
questions.answer: D. IPv6 traffic filtering can be implemented only on SVIs.
questions.answer_description:
OSPFv3 uses link-local IPv6 addresses for neighbor discovery and other features, so if any IPv6 traffic filters are implemented be sure to include the link local address so that it is permitted in the filter list.
Reference: http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/datacenter/sw/5_x/nx- os/unicast/configuration/guide/l3_cli_nxos/l3_ospfv3.html

discussion.content: C. The link-local addresses that were used by OSPFv3 were explicitly denied, which caused the neighbor relationships to fail.

questions.question_text: What is the purpose of the autonomous-system {autonomous-system-number} command?

discussion.content: A. It sets the EIGRP autonomous system number in a VRF.

choices.B: It sets the BGP autonomous system number in a VRF.
choices.A: It sets the EIGRP autonomous system number in a VRF.
choices.C: It sets the global EIGRP autonomous system number.

questions.answer: D. It sets the global BGP autonomous system number.
questions.answer_ET: D. It sets the global BGP autonomous system number.
questions.answer_description:
To configure the autonomous-system number for an Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing Protocol (EIGRP) routing process to run within a VPN routing and forwarding (VRF) instance, use the autonomous-system command in address-family configuration mode. To remove the autonomous-system for an EIGRP routing process from within a VPN VRF instance, use the no form of this command. autonomous-systemautonomous-system-number no autonomous-systemautonomous-system-number
Reference:
http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/iproute_eigrp/command/reference/ire_book/ire_a1.htm l#wp1062796

choices.B: The networks were not advertised properly under the OSPFv3 process.
choices.C: An IPv6 traffic filter is blocking the networks from being learned via the Router B interface that is connected to Router A.
choices.A: OSPFv3 timers were adjusted for fast convergence.

questions.question_text: Router A and Router B are configured with IPv6 addressing and basic routing capabilities using OSPFv3. The networks that are advertised from Router A do not show up in Router B's routing table. After debugging IPv6 packets, the message "not a router" is found in the output. Why is the routing information not being learned by Router B?
questions.answer_description:
show ipv6 traffic Field Descriptions

Field Description -
source- Number of source-routed packets.
routed
truncated Number of truncated packets.
format Errors that can result from checks performed on header fields, errors the version number, and packet length. not a Message sent when IPv6 unicast routing is not enabled. router
Reference:
http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/ios/ipv6/command/reference/ipv6_book/ipv6_16.html
questions.answer_ET: D. IPv6 unicast routing is not enabled on Router A or Router B.
questions.answer: D. IPv6 unicast routing is not enabled on Router A or Router B.

discussion.content: D. IPv6 unicast routing is not enabled on Router A or Router B.

questions.answer_ET: D. DHCP messages where the destination MAC and client MAC do not match
questions.question_text: Which type of traffic does DHCP snooping drop?

choices.B: DHCP messages where the source MAC and client MAC do not match
choices.C: traffic from a trusted DHCP server to client

questions.answer: D. DHCP messages where the destination MAC and client MAC do not match
questions.answer_description:
The switch validates DHCP packets received on the untrusted interfaces of VLANs with DHCP snooping enabled. The switch forwards the DHCP packet unless any of the following conditions occur (in which case the packet is dropped):

The switch receives a packet (such as a DHCPOFFER, DHCPACK, DHCPNAK, or DHCPLEASEQUERY packet) from a DHCP server outside the network or firewall.

The switch receives a packet on an untrusted interface, and the source MAC address and the DHCP client hardware address do not match. This check is performed only if the DHCP snooping MAC address verification option is turned on.

The switch receives a DHCPRELEASE or DHCPDECLINE message from an untrusted host with an entry in the DHCP snooping binding table, and the interface information in the binding table does not match the interface on which the message was received.

The switch receives a DHCP packet that includes a relay agent IP address that is not 0.0.0.0. To support trusted edge switches that are connected to untrusted aggregation-switch ports, you can enable the DHCP option-82 on untrusted port feature, which enables untrusted aggregation- switch ports to accept DHCP packets that include option-82 information. Configure the port on the edge switch that connects to the aggregation switch as a trusted port. Reference: http:// www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst6500/ios/12- 2SX/configuration/guide/book/snoodhcp.html

discussion.content: B. DHCP messages where the source MAC and client MAC do not match
